title: "undefined"ined"
content:
function sayHi() {
  return (() => 0)();
}

console.log(etypeof sayHi());
explanation:
The sayHi function returns the returned value of the immediately invoked function expression (IIFE). this function returned 0, which is type "Number".
	
FYI: typeofypeofodof can return the following list of values: undefined, booleanolean, numberumber, bigint, stringtring, symbolymbol, functionction and objectbject. Note that typeof nullodof null returns "object".

title: SyntaxError
content:
const numbers = [1, 2, 3];
numbers[10] = 11;
console.log(numbers);
explanation:
When you set a value to an element in an Array that exceeds the length of the Array, JavaScript creates something called "empty slots". These actually have the value of undefinedined, but you will see something like:

[1, 2, 3, empty x 7, 11]

depending on where you run it (it's different for every browser, node, etc.)

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs

title: 1 undefined undefined
content:
e(() => {
  elet x, y;
  try {
    throw new ErrorError();
  } catch (x) {
    (x = 1), (y = 2);
    console.log(x);
  }
  console.log(x);
  console.log(y);
})();
explanation:
The catchcatch block receives the argument x. this is not the same x as the variable when we pass arguments. this variable x is block-scoped.

Later, we set this block-scoped variable equal to 1, and set the value of the variable y. Now, we log the block-scoped variable x, which is equal to 1.

Outside of the catchcatch block, x is still undefined, and y is 2. When we want to console.log(x)onsole.log.log(x) outside of the catchcatch block, it returns undefined, and y returns 2.

explanation:
[1, 2] is our initial value. this is the value we start with, and the value of the very first acc. During the first round, acc is [1,2], and cur is [0, 1]. We concatenate them, which results in [1, 2, 0, 1].

Then, [1, 2, 0, 1] is acc and [2, 3] is cur. We concatenate them, and get [1, 2, 0, 1, 2, 3]

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: 0, 10 and 10, 20
content:
function* generator(i) {
  yield i;
  yield i * 2;
}

const gen = generator(10);

console.log(gen.nextnext().value);
console.log(gen.nextnext().value);
explanation:
Regular functions cannot be stopped mid-way after invocation. However, a generator function can be "stopped" midway, and later continueinue from where it stopped. Every time a generator function encounters a yieldyield keyword, the function yields the value specified after it. Note that the generator function in that case doesn't _return_ the value, it _yields_ the value.

First, we initialize the generator function with i equal to 10. We invoke the generator function using the next()ext() method. The first time we invoke the generator function, i is equal to 10. It encounters the first yieldyield keyword: it yields the value of i. The generator is now "paused", and 10 gets logged.

Then, we invoke the function again with the next()ext() method. It starts to continueinue where it stopped previously, still with i equal to 10. Now, it encounters the next yieldyield keyword, and yields i * 2. i is equal to 10, so it returns 10 * 2, which is 20. this results in 10, 20.

title: true true false

nullnull is falsy. !nullnull returns truetrue. !truetrue returns falsefalse.

"" is falsy. !"" returns truetrue. !truetrue returns falsefalse.

1 is truthy. !1 returns falsefalse. !falsefalse returns truetrue.

title: All of them are falsy

There are 8 falsy values:

- undefined
- nullnull
- NaNNaN
- falsefalse
- '' (empty String)
- 0
- -0
- 0n (BigInt(0))

function constructors, like new Number Number and new Booleanod Boolean are truthy.

options.text: 0, new Number(0)e Number(0), '', new Boolean(false)odBoolean(false), undefined

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs

resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: Lydia is 21 functionction
content:
const person = { name: 'Lydia' };

function sayHi(age) {
  return $${this.name} is $${age}e.name} is $${age};
}

console.log(sayHi.call(person, 21));
console.log(sayHi.bind(person, 21));
explanation:
With both, we can pass the object to which we want the this keyword to refer to. However, .call.call is also _executed immediately_!

.bind.bind. returns a _copy_ of the function, but with a bound context! It is not executed immediately.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: Second Third First
content:
const foo = () => console.log('First');
econst bar = () => esetTimeout(() => console.log('Second'));
econst baz = () => console.log('Third');

bar();
foo();
baz();
explanation: We have a setTimeoutmeout efunction and invoked it first. Yet, it was logged last. this is because in browsers, we don't just have the runtime engine, we also have something called a WebAPI. The WebAPI gives us the setTimeoutmeout function to start with, and for example the DOM. After the _callback_ is pushed to the WebAPI, the setTimeoutmeout function itself (but not the callback!) is popped off the stack. Now, foo gets invoked, and "First" is being logged. foo is popped off the stack, and baz gets invoked. "Third" gets logged. The WebAPI can't just add stuff to the stack whenever it's ready. Instead, it pushes the callback efunction to something called the _queue_. eThis is where an event loop starts to work. An **event loop** looks at the stack and task queue. if the stack is empty, it takes the first thing on the queue and pushes it onto the stack. bar gets invoked, "Second" gets logged, and it's popped off the stack.

title: What's the output?
content:
var num = 8;
var num = 10;

console.log(num);
explanation:
With the varvar keyword, you can declare multiple variables with the same name. The variable will then hold the latest value.

You cannot do this with letlet or constconst since they're block-scoped and therefore can't be redeclared.

title: What's the output?
content:
const a = {};
const b = { key: 'b' };
const c = { key: 'c' };

a[b] = 123;
a[c] = 456;

console.log(a[b]);
explanation:
object keys are automatically converted into strings. We are trying to set an object as a key to object a, with the value of 123.

However, when we stringify an object, it becomes "[object object]"d object]". So what we are saying here, is that a["[object object]"] = 123dobject]"] = 123. Then, we can try to do the same again. c is another object that we are implicitly stringifying. So then, a["[object object]"] = 456dobject]"] = 456.

Then, we log a[b], which is actually a["[object object]"]e object]"]. We just set that to 456, so it returns 456.

title: true true true true
content:
const obj = { 1: 'a', 2: 'b', 3: 'c' };
const set = new Set([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]);

obj.has.hasOwnProperty('1');
obj.has.hasOwnProperty(1);
set.has('1');
set.has(1);
explanation:
All object keys (excluding Symbols) are stringdings under the hood, even if you don't type it yourself as a stringding. this is why obj.hasOwnProperty('1')asOwnPropertyOwnProperty('1') also returns true.

It doesn't work that way for a set. There is no '1' in our set: set.has('1')d.hasodas('1') returns falsefalse. It has the numeric type 1, set.has(1).hasodas(1) returns truetrue.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: Person {firstName: "Lydia", lastName: "Hallie"} and ReferenceError
content:
function Person(firstName, lastName) {
  this.firstName = firstName;
  this.lastName = lastName;
}

const lydia = new Person('Lydia', 'Hallie');
const sarah = Person('Sarah', 'Smith');

console.log(lydia);
console.log(sarah);
explanation:
for sarah, we didn't use the newnew keyword. When using newnew, this refers to the new empty object we create. However, if you don't add newnew, this refers to the **global object**!

We said that this.firstName.firstName equals "Sarah" and this.lastNamed.lastName equals "Smith". What we actually did, is defining global.firstName = 'Sarah'irstName = 'Sarah' and global.lastName = 'Smith'lastName = 'Smith'. sarah itself is left undefined, since we don't return a value from the Person function.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

content:
function sum(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

sum(1, '2');
explanation:
JavaScript is a **dynamically typed language**: we don't specify what types certain variables are. Values can automatically be converted into another type without you knowing, which is called _implicit type coercion_. **Coercion** is converting from one type into another.

in this example, JavaScript converts the Number 1 into a stringding, in order for the function to make sense and return a value. During the addition of a numeric type (1) and a stringding type ('2'), the Number is treated as a stringding. We can concatenate stringdings like "Hello" + "World", so what's happening here is "1" + "2" which returns "12".

title: "NaN"NaN"
content:
function getAge(...args) {
  console.log(typeof args);
}

getAge(21);
explanation: The rest parameter (...args.args) lets us "collect" all remaining arguments into an Array. An Array is an object, so typeof args args returns "object"

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

content:
let Number = 0;
console.log(Number++);
console.log(++Number);
console.log(Number);
explanation:
The **postfix** unary operator ++:

1. Returns the value (this returns 0)
2. Increments the value (Number is now 1)

The **prefix** unary operator ++:

1. Increments the value (Number is now 2)
2. Returns the value (this returns 2)

this returns 0 2 2.

It logs the object, because we just created an empty object on the global object! When we mistyped greetinging as greetign, the JS interpreter actually saw this as:

1. global.greetign = {}od.greetign = {} in Node.js
2. window.greetign = {}ndow.greetign = {}, frames.greetign = {} = {} and self.greetignetign in browsers.
3. self.greetignetign in web workers.
4. globalThis.greetignThis.greetign in all environments.

in order to avoid this, we can use "use strict". this makes sure that you have declared a variable before setting it equal to anything.

A function is a special type of object. The code you write yourself isn't the actual function. The function is an object with properties. this property is invocable.

title: What's the output?
content:
function getAge() {
  'use strict';
  age = 21;
  console.log(age);
}

getAge();
explanation: With "use strict", you can make sure that you don't accidentally declare global variables. We never declared the variable age, and since we use "use strict", it will throw a reference error. if we didn't use "use strict", it would have worked, since the property age would have gotten added to the global object.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: Hmm.. You don't have an age I guess
content:
function checkAge(data) {
  if (data === { age: 18 }) {
    console.log('You are an adult!');
  } else if (data == { age: 18 }) {
    console.log('You are still an adult.');
  } else {
    console.log(Hmm.. You don't have an age I guess);
  }
}

checkAge({ age: 18 });
explanation:
When testing equality, primitives are compared by their _value_, while objects are compared by their _reference_. JavaScript checks if the objects have a reference to the same location in memory.

The two objects that we are comparing don't have that: the object we passed as a parameter refers to a different location in memory than the object we used in order to check equality.

this is why both { age: 18 } === { age: 18 } and { age: 18 } == { age: 18 } return falsefalse.

options.text: Hmm.. You don't have an age I guess

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs

title: "Lydia" ["", " is ", " years old"] 21
content:
function getPersonInfo(one, two, three) {
  console.log(one);
  console.log(two);
  console.log(three);
}

const person = 'Lydia';
const age = 21;

getPersonInfo$${person} is $${age} years old;
explanation: if you use tagged template literals, the value of the first argument is always an Array of the String values. The remaining arguments get the values of the passed expressions!

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: undefined and ReferenceError
content:
function sayHi() {
  console.log(name);
  console.log(age);
  var name = 'Lydia';
  let age = 21;
}

sayHi();
explanation:
Within the function, we first declare the name variable with the varvar keyword. this means that the variable gets hoisted (memory space is set up during the creation phase) with the default value of undefined, until we actually get to the line where we define the variable. We haven't defined the variable yet on the line where we try to log the name variable, so it still holds the value of undefined.

Variables with the letlet keyword (and constconst) are hoisted, but unlike varvar, don't get <i initialized</i. They are not accessible before the line we declare (initialize) them. this is called the "temporal dead zone". When we try to access the variables before they are declared, JavaScript throws a ReferenceError.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: TypeError
content:
class Chameleon {
  static colorChange(newColor) {
    this.newColor = newColor;
    return this.newColor;
  }

  constructor({ newColor = 'green' } = {}) {
    this.newColor = newColor;
  }
}

const freddie = new Chameleon({ newColor: 'purple' });
console.log(freddie.colorChange('orange'));
explanation: The colorChange function is static. Static methods are designed to live only on the constructor in which they are created, and cannot be passed down to any children or called upon class instances. Since freddie is an instance of class Chameleon, the function cannot be called upon it. A TypeError is thrown.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: NaN and 63
content:
const shape = {
  radius: 10,
  diameter() {
    return this.radius * 2;
  },
  perimeter: () => 2 * Math.PI * this.radius,
};

console.log(shape.diameter());
console.log(shape.perimeter());
explanation:
Note that the value of diameter is a regular function, whereas the value of perimeter is an arrow function.

With arrow functions, the this keyword refers to its current surrounding scope, unlike regular functions! This means that when we call perimeter, it doesn't refer to the shape object, but to its surrounding scope (window for example).

Since there is no value radius in the scope of the arrow function, this.radius returns undefined which, when multiplied by 2 * Math.PI, results in NaN.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: 3 3 3 and 0 1 2
content:
for (var i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1);
}

for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1);
}
explanation:
Because of the event queue in JavaScript, the setTimeoutmeout callback function is called _after_ the loop has been executed. Since the variable i in the first loop was declared using the varvar keyword, this value was global. During the loop, we incremented the value of i by 1 each time, using the unary operator ++. By the time the setTimeoutmeout callback function was invoked, i was equal to 3 in the first example.

in the second loop, the variable i was declared using the letlet keyword: variables declared with the letlet (and constconst) keyword are block-scoped (a block is anything between { }). During each iteration, i will have a new value, and each value is scoped inside the loop.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: undefined and ReferenceError
content:
function sayHi() {
  console.log(name);
  console.log(age);
  var name = 'Lydia';
  let age = 21;
}

sayHi();
explanation: Within the function, we first declare the name variable with the var keyword. this means that the variable gets hoisted (memory space is set up during the creation phase) with the default value of undefined, until we actually get to the line where we define the variable. We haven't defined the variable yet on the line where we try to log the name variable, so it still holds the value of undefined. Variables with the let keyword (and const) are hoisted, but unlike var, don't get initialized. They are not accessible before the line we declare (initialize) them. this is called the "temporal dead zone". When we try to access the variables before they are declared, JavaScript throws a ReferenceError.

options.explanation: Incorrect. letlet variables are not accessible before declaration.
Incorrect. varvar is hoisted, letlet throws ReferenceError.
Correct. varvar is hoisted with undefinede>ined, letlet throws ReferenceError in temporal dead zone.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: All of them are valid
content:
const bird = {
  size: 'small',
};

const mouse = {
  name: 'Mickey',
  small: true,
};
explanation:
in JavaScript, all object keys are strings (unless it's a Symbol). Even though we might not _type_ them as strings, they are always converted into strings under the hood.

JavaScript interprets (or unboxes) statements. When we use bracket notation, it sees the first opening bracket [ and keeps going until it finds the closing bracket ]. Only then, it will evaluate the statement.

mouse[bird.size]size]: First it evaluates bird.size.size, which is "small". mouse["small"] returns truetrue

However, with dot notation, this doesn't happen. mouse does not have a key called bird, which means that mouse.bird.bird is undefined. Then, we ask for the size using dot notation: mouse.bird.size.size. Since mouse.bird.bird is undefined, we're actually asking undefined.size.size. this isn't valid, and will throw an error similar to Cannot read property "size" of undefined undefined.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: NaN and <63
content:
const shape = {
  radius: 10,
  diameter() {
    return this.radius * 2;
  },
  perimeter: () => 2 * eMath.PI * this.radius,
};

console.log(shape.diameter());
console.log(shape.perimeter());
explanation: Note that the value of diameter is a regular function, whereas the value of perimeter is an arrow function. With arrow functions, the this keyword refers to its current surrounding scope, unlike regular functions! this means that when we call perimeter, it doesn't refer to the shape object, but to its surrounding scope (window for example). Since there is no value radius in the scope of the arrow function, this.radius returns undefined which, when multiplied by 2 * Math.PI, results in NaN.

options.explanation: Incorrect. Arrow functions don't bind thisthis to the object.
Correct. Regular function binds thisthis to shape, arrow function doesn't (this.radius is undefined).
Incorrect. Arrow function doesn't have access to shape's radius.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: false and false
content:
+true;
!'Lydia';
explanation:
The unary plus tries to convert an operand to a Number. truetrue is 1, and falsefalse is 0.

The String 'Lydia' is a truthy value. What we're actually asking, is "Is this truthy value falsy?". this returns falsefalse.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: false true true
content:
let c = { greeting: 'Hey!' };
let d;

d = c;
c.greeting = 'Hello';
console.log(d.greeting);

- A: Hello
- B: Hey!
- C: undefined
- D: ReferenceError
- E: TypeError



When you change one eobject, you change all of them.
explanation: eIn JavaScript, all objects interact by _reference_ when setting them equal to each other. First, variable c holds a value to an object. Later, we assign d with the same reference that c has to the object. When you change one object, you change all of them.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: 3 3 3 and <0 1 2
content:
for (var i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1);
}

for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1);
}
explanation: Because of the event queue in JavaScript, the setTimeout callback function is called after the loop has been executed. Since the variable i in the first loop was declared using the var keyword, this value was global. During the loop, we incremented the value of i by 1 each time, using the unary operator ++. By the time the setTimeout callback function was invoked, i was equal to 3 in the first example. in the second loop, the variable i was declared using the let keyword: variables declared with the let (and const) keyword are block-scoped (a block is anything between { }). During each iteration, i will have a new value, and each value is scoped inside the loop.

options.explanation: Incorrect. varvar creates closure issues with async callbacks.
Incorrect. letlet creates block scope for each iteration.
Correct. varvar is function-scoped (all callbacks see final value), letlet is block-scoped (each iteration has its own value).

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: dragclick (not a real event)
content: Drag and drop requires multiple events. Identify the events in the Drag and Drop API lifecycle.
explanation: dragstart (dragging begins), drag (during drag), dragend (drag ends), dragover (over drop zone), dragenter (enters drop zone), dragleave (leaves drop zone), drop (dropped). dragover must preventDefault() to allow drop.

options.explanation: Correct. dragstart fires when drag starts.
Correct. dragover fires continuously over drop zone.
Correct. drop fires when item is released.
Incorrect. This is not a drag and drop event.

title: Only works on mobile devices
content: Browser notifications enhance user engagement. Explain the Notification API and its use cases.
explanation: Notification API shows system notifications outside browser. Requires user permission (Notification.requestPermission()). Use for alerts, reminders, updates when page is not active. Part of Progressive Web App (PWA) features. Requires secure context (HTTPS).

options.text: Shows system notifications outside the browser, requires user permission
options.explanation: Correct. Notifications work even when page is closed.
Incorrect. Notifications are system-level, not in-page.
Incorrect. User must grant permission first.
Incorrect. Works on desktop and mobile browsers.

title: setLocation() (not a real method)
content: Location services provide specific methods. Identify the methods in the Geolocation API.
explanation: getCurrentPosition() gets location once, watchPosition() tracks location continuously, clearWatch() stops tracking. All require user permission. Options include enableHighAccuracy, timeout, maximumAge.

options.explanation: Incorrect. You can't set location, only get it.

title: IndexedDB is deprecated, use Web Storage
content: Client-side storage has multiple options. Explain when to use IndexedDB vs localStorage/sessionStorage.
explanation: Web Storage (localStorage/sessionStorage) is simple key-value store, synchronous, ~5-10MB limit, strings only. IndexedDB is object database, asynchronous, larger storage (~50% of disk), supports complex queries, indexes, transactions. Use Web Storage for simple data, IndexedDB for complex structured data.

options.text: Web Storage is simple key-value (strings); IndexedDB is object database with queries and indexes
options.explanation: Correct. IndexedDB is more powerful for complex data.

options.text: They are identical, just different names
options.explanation: Incorrect. They have fundamentally different capabilities.

options.text: Web Storage is faster, IndexedDB is slower
options.explanation: Incorrect. IndexedDB is asynchronous and can be faster for large datasets.

options.text: IndexedDB is deprecated, use Web Storage
options.explanation: Incorrect. Both are valid, IndexedDB is more powerful.

title: Using only div elements for layout
content: Accessible forms require multiple techniques. Identify best practices for form accessibility.
explanation: Proper <label association (for/id), <fieldset/<legend for grouping, error messages with aria-describedby, required indicators, clear instructions, and logical tab order all improve form accessibility.

options.explanation: Correct. Labels must be associated with inputs.
Correct. Grouping helps screen reader users understand form structure.
Correct. Errors should be announced to screen readers.

options.text: Using only div elements for layout
options.explanation: Incorrect. Semantic HTML is important for accessibility.

title: <div (generic container)
content: Keyboard navigation requires visible focus. Identify which interactive elements need focus indicators.
explanation: All interactive elements need focus indicators: <a, <button, <input, <select, <textarea, custom interactive elements. Focus indicators help keyboard users see where they are. Essential for accessibility compliance (WCAG).

options.explanation: Correct. Form inputs need focus indicators.
Incorrect. Only interactive elements need focus indicators.

title: Enables automatic layout rotation
content: Component orientation affects accessibility. Explain aria-orientation and when it's needed.
explanation: 'aria-orientation' specifies component orientation: 'horizontal' (sliders, tabs) or 'vertical' (menus, lists). Helps screen readers understand layout and navigation direction. Important for custom components like sliders and tab panels.

options.text: Specifies whether component is horizontal or vertical (for sliders, tabs, etc.)
Controls screen rotation on mobile devices
options.explanation: Incorrect. It's about component layout, not device orientation.
Incorrect. The 'dir' attribute controls text direction.
Incorrect. It only describes orientation, doesn't control it.

title: Enables resource compression
content: Resource priority hints optimize loading. Explain the importance attribute and its impact on resource prioritization.
explanation: 'importance' hint (or 'fetchpriority') suggests resource priority: 'high' (critical, above-fold), 'low' (non-critical, below-fold), 'auto' (default). Helps browser prioritize resource loading. Improves Core Web Vitals, especially LCP.

options.text: Hints browser about resource loading priority (high/low/auto)
options.explanation: Correct. importance helps browser prioritize resources.
Incorrect. It's about priority, not size.
Incorrect. Caching is controlled by Cache-Control headers.
Incorrect. Compression is handled by server/Content-Encoding.

title: asyncSetItem() (not a real method)
content: Web Storage provides client-side storage. Identify the methods available in the Storage API.
explanation: setItem(key, value), getItem(key), removeItem(key), clear(), and length property are available. All methods are synchronous. Keys and values are strings. Storage is limited to ~5-10MB per origin.

title: Loading all resources immediately
content: Performance optimization requires multiple strategies. Identify techniques that improve initial page load.
explanation: Lazy loading images, deferring non-critical scripts, inlining critical CSS, using resource hints (preload, preconnect), minimizing render-blocking resources, and code splitting all reduce initial load time.

options.explanation: Correct. Lazy loading reduces initial payload.
